words.ENTRY: <H>dance</H><su>1</su><audio>dance.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>a series of steps and movements which you do to music:</D> <X>What type of dance is this? A waltz?</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>dancing as a form of art or entertainment:</D> <X>She's very interested in modern dance.</X><H>dance</H><su>2</su><audio>dance.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>to move around to the rhythm of music by making a series of steps:</D> <X>to dance the waltz</X><NR>2.</NR><D>to move in a lively way, usually up and down:</D> <X>She was dancing up and down with excitement.</X>

<H>dangerous</H><audio>dangerous.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>likely to cause injury or damage:</D> <X>a dangerous animal/road/illness</X><dot><X>The strong currents in the ocean here are extremely dangerous for swimmers.</X>

<H>dark</H><audio>dark.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>(used about a color) nearer black than white; not light:</D> <X>dark blue</X><dot><X>He has dark eyes.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>with no light or very little light:</D> <X>It was a dark night, with no moon.</X>

<H>date</H><su>1</su><audio>date.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a particular day of the month or of the year:</D> <X>What's the date today?</X><dot><X>What's your date of birth/your birth date?</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>an appointment to meet somebody, especially a boyfriend or girlfriend:</D> <X>I'm going out on a date with Tom on Friday night.</X><NR>3.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person that you have made an appointment to meet, especially a boyfriend or girlfriend:</D> <X>Sarah introduced us to her date at the party.</X><H>date</H><su>2</su><audio>date.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to meet a girlfriend or boyfriend regularly:</D> <X>Joe and Sue have been dating for 6 months.</X>

<H>day</H><audio>day.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a period of 24 hours, of which seven make up a week:</D> <X>"What day is it today?" "Tuesday."</X><dot><X>We went to Hawaii for ten days.</X><dot><X>I saw that movie a few days ago.</X><dot><X>New Year's Day</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the period of time after the sun rises and before it sets:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>The days were warm, but the nights were freezing.</X><dot><X>Have a nice day! See you tonight.</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>It's been raining all day.</X>
<H>delicious</H><audio>delicious.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>(usually about food) having a very pleasant taste or smell:</D> <X>What are you cooking? It smells delicious.</X>
<H>department store</H><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a large store that is divided into departments selling many different types of goods</D>

<H>designer</H><audio>designer.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person whose job is to make drawings showing how something will be made:</D> <X>a fashion designer</X><dot><X>designer clothing</X> (= made by a famous designer)

dictionarynouncountable(plural dictionaries) a book that lists the words of a language in alphabetical order and that tells you what they mean in the same or another language: to look up a word in a dictionarya bilingual/monolingual dictionarya French-English dictionary

<H>dinner</H><audio>dinner.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the main meal of the day, eaten either at noon or (usually) in the evening:</D> <bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>What's for dinner, Mom?</X><dot><X>It's time for dinner.</X><dot><bracket>countable</bracket><X>That was a great dinner you cooked.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a formal occasion in the evening during which a meal is served:</D> <X>A dinner was given for the celebrity.</X>

do1auxiliary verb(negative do not; negative short form don't; third person singular does; third person singular negative does not; third person singular negative short form doesn't; past did; past negative did not; past negative short form didn't) 1.(used with other verbs to form questions and negative sentences, also in short answers and tag questions): Do you know John?He doesn't live in Portland."Do you agree?" "No, I don't./Yes, I do."She works in Montreal, doesn't she?2.(used for emphasizing the main verb): "Why didn't you buy any milk?" "I did buy some. It's in the fridge."3.(used to avoid repeating the main verb): He earns a lot more than I do.She's feeling a lot better than she did last week.do2verb(present participle doing; third person singular does; past did; past participle done) 1.to perform an action: What are you doing?We didn't do much yesterday.Please do as you're told.What do you do? (= What is your job?) 2.to carry out a particular activity: Did he do his homework?Who does the cooking in your house?3.to make progress or develop: How are you doing? (= How are you?)"How's your daughter doing at school?" "She's doing well." (= She is successful.)

<H>doctor</H><audio>doctor.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>a person who has been trained in medical science and who treats people who are sick:</D> <X>Our family doctor is Dr. Young.</X><dot><X>I have a doctor's appointment at 10 o'clock.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>a person who has received the highest degree from a university:</D> <X>Doctor of Philosophy</X>

doornouncountable1.a piece of wood, glass, etc. that
you open and close to get in or out of a room, building, car, etc.: to open/shut/close the doorDon't forget to lock the door when you leave the house.2.the entrance to a building, room, car, etc.: I peeked through the door and saw her sitting there. next door (to somebody/something) in the next house, room, etc.: Do you know the people (who live) next door?You'll find the bathroom next door to your bedroom.

<H>downtown</H><audio>downtown.mp3</audio><PS>adjective;</PS> <PS>adverb</PS><D>in or to the central area of a city or large town, especially where there are many stores and businesses:</D> <X>downtown Milwaukee</X><dot><X>I need to go downtown and get some things for the party.</X>

dragverb(present participle dragging; past participle dragged)1.to move some text, etc., across the screen of a computer using a mouse 2.to pull somebody/something along with difficulty: The box was so heavy that we had to drag it along the floor.

<H>drama</H><audio>drama.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a play for the theater, radio, or television:</D> <X>a contemporary drama</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>plays as a form of writing; the performance of plays:</D> <X>He wrote some drama as well as poetry.</X><dot><X>a drama student</X>
<H>dress</H><audio>dress.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a piece of clothing worn by a girl or a woman. It covers the body from the shoulders to the knees or below.</D>

drink1verb(simple past drank; past participle drunk) 1.to take liquid into your body through your mouth: You've lost a lot of fluid. You need to keep drinking.I never drink coffee.2.to drink alcohol: Don't drink and drive.drink2nouncountable, uncountable1.liquid for drinking: countableCan I have a drink?a drink of milkuncountablefood and drink2.alcoholic drink: a strong drink

driveverb(past drove; past participle driven) 1.to control or operate a car/train/bus: Can you drive?to drive a car/train/bus/truck2.to go or take somebody somewhere in a car, etc.: I usually drive to work.We drove Nancy to the airport.
<H>driver</H><audio>driver.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person who drives a vehicle:</D> <X>Are you the driver of this car?</X>

<H>during</H><audio>during.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>for all of a period of time:</D> <X>The audience must remain seated during the performance.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>on more than one occasion in a period of time:</D> <X>During the summer vacation we went swimming every day.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>at some point in a period of time:</D> <X>Did you hear a strange noise during the night?</X>
